subject: RE: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test

messageBody:
Peter O'Neill wrote:
> When I run my test suite I found that each test stops running
> after the
> first failed assertion. I have a number of assertions in each
> test and I
> would like to know every assertion that is broken. I have tried to
> create a default TestResult inside each test using,
>
> TestResult result = createResult();
>
> and then adding failures to 'result' using,
>
> result.addFailure(mytest, afe);
>
> which works fine, except that no AssertionFailedException gets thrown
> this way and my test passes even though I have broken assertions.
>
> Is there any way I can get JUnit to show all broken
> assertions for each
> test and not move onto the next test when the first assertion fails?

You can not do this easily within JUnit. The reason is simple: the various
assertXYZ() methods throw Errors when they fail, and Java does not permit
unwinding an exception stack trace so you can pick up where the exception
occurred.

In many cases, you wouldn't want to, anyway. Having an error at point X
would often mean that more errors would be reported due to the first one (in
much the same way a simple typo can spawn numerous compilation errors).

The right way, to get the same effect, is to have smaller test methods. If
you find that you are using a lot of common setup code, extract that out to
a helper method, or create a new test class and use the setUp() method.

The hard (and wrong) way is to change the assertion semantics. Define your
own TestCase class, and provide new assertion methods so that, instead of
throwing an Error, you add the failure to a collection. Then, use a
TestDecorator so that you can inspect the collection for errors, and fail
the test at that point. Note that you will probably have to build your own
Test suite to do this (the inbuilt reflection support won't place the
decorator in for you)

Robert.
